comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Helen Harris identified as "Helen of Troy": Berkman, who was accompanied by a girl known as "Helen of Troy," but who gave her name as Helen Harris, walked around town followed by a crowd of thousands. — Greensburg Daily Tribune, 1 June 1914 Her actual last name might be Goldblat(t): Alexander Berkman and Becky Edelson led 20 anarchists into a police station early today ... Helen Goldblat, known as "Helen of Troy;" her sister, Lillian; William Shatoff and Abraham Blecker. — The Day 9 November 1914 Helen Goldblatt, known as "Helen of Troy," and her sister Lillian, who completed week ago ten days' sentences in tile Workhouse — New York Times 27 November 1914 (Lillian might be Lillian Rubel.)

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: Thanks so much for connecting up the pictures, people, and event, and finding several sources that help identify Helen Harris/of Troy/Goldblatt (an oral history of the Anarchist movement spells it with two t's). We'll add information to the description when we update.
